repnme.cdata!: India - First Bihar Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Bihar Development
            Policy Loan Project (BDPL-1) for India were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: first, BDPL-1 reaffirms the
            importance of the comprehensive, multi-sector policy
            dialogue with the highest levels of government that a DPL
            provides. The three pillars of the DPL on fiscal management
            and governance, growth, and service delivery, provided
            convening power because they mapped closely into the
            Government's 11th Five Year plan and endorsed its core
            ideas. The pillars also provided the basis for the more
            coherent framework for development partnerships that Bihar
            was able to organize, important in a state where limited
            capacities could have been further fragmented by poor donor
            coordination. Second, gauging the political economy of
            reforms is vital for a DPL. A key lesson that BDPL-1 reminds
            us of is the vital importance of gauging the domestic
            politics within which clients must function and assessing
            how their reform ownership might evolve. This is important
            everywhere, but doubly so where administrative capacity is
            low, governance has been poor and the track record thin.
            Third, a DPL should strengthen the role of monitoring and
            evaluation (M&E) in government and promote
            evidence-based policymaking. It can do so by identifying a
            good result framework that is measureable and consistent
            with the capacities of the client and that can provide
            assurance that the government's programs are sound and
            producing desirable outcomes. Fourth, a DPL should
            synchronize technical assistance with realistic capacity
            building objectives especially in situations of still low
            capacity. From the perspective of individual Bihar
            Government departments or entities other than the Finance
            Department, technical assistance and economic and sector
            work were the two tangible elements associated with the DPL
            that they could see and benefit from. Fifth, the BDPL-I
            shows the need to maintain the long-term, special
            relationship with Bihar that a DPL makes possible.

docna.cdata!: India - First Bihar Development Policy Loan Project

India - First Bihar Development

            IMMEDIATE RELIEF EFFORT (GFDRR: TRACK II TA)

repnme.cdata!:
Helping India's Bihar State boost
            public services through better management

abstracts.cdata!:
India's Bihar state is home to some
            of India's poorest people but a new reform effort by
            the Bihar government, backed by World Bank funding and
            technical support has helped it improve public finance
            management and direct the proceeds to getting more children
            into schools, to immunizing its people, and to fighting corruption.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Reforms boost funding for roads,
            education and health in Bihar

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on the
            finance reform in Bihar, India. Bihar is one of the largest
            and poorest states in India. Two million children between 6
            and 13 years of age were out of school and the literacy rate
            was at 48 percent. Bihar’s public services and
            infrastructure were among the worst in India. Nearly 60
            percent of homes in the state were not connected to roads,
            only 21 percent of households had access to piped water, and
            electricity was not available to the vast majority of
            households. International Bank for Reconstruction and
            Development (IBRD) supported Bihar government through Bihar
            Development Policy Loan to boost economic growth through
            reforms in agriculture, investment climate and basic
            infrastructure, with an emphasis on roads. The funding from
            IBRD helped create fiscal space for development by financing
            the government’s budgeted expenditures including retiring
            expensive public debt. Bihar’s tax revenues had increased by
            an impressive 19 percent annually since the reform program
            began. About 1,900 kilometers of the national highway along
            with 3,432 kilometers of district roads network were
            renovated by 2009. The government extended its midday meal
            scheme to cover children in grades six through eight,
            thereby increasing the program’s reach to nearly 11 million
            children. Bihar government, backed by World Bank funding and
            technical support, has helped Bihar improve public finance
            management and direct the proceeds toward getting more
            children into schools, immunization, and fighting corruption

docna.cdata!:
India - Reformas fomentan financiamiento de
            caminos, educación y salud

display_title.display_title:
India - Reforms boost funding for
            roads, education and health in Bihar : India - Reformas
            fomentan financiamiento de caminos, educación y salud

            infrastructure were among the worst in India. Nearly 60
            percent of homes in the state were not connected to roads,
            only 21 percent of households had access to piped water, and
            electricity was not available to the vast majority of
            households. International Bank for Reconstruction and
            Development (IBRD) supported Bihar government through Bihar
            Development Policy Loan to boost economic growth through
            reforms in agriculture, investment climate and basic
            infrastructure, with an emphasis on roads. The funding from
            IBRD helped create fiscal space for development by financing
            the government’s budgeted expenditures including retiring
            expensive public debt. Bihar’s tax revenues had increased by
            an impressive 19 percent annually since the reform program
            began. About 1,900 kilometers of the national highway along
            with 3,432 kilometers of district roads network were
            renovated by 2009. The government extended its midday meal
            scheme to cover children in grades six through eight,
            thereby increasing the program’s reach to nearly 11 million
            children. Bihar government, backed by World Bank funding and
            technical support, has helped Bihar improve public finance
            management and direct the proceeds toward getting more
            children into schools, immunization, and fighting corruption

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on the
            finance reform in Bihar, India. Bihar is one of the largest
            and poorest states in India. Two million children between 6
            and 13 years of age were out of school and the literacy rate
            was at 48 percent. Bihar’s public services and
            infrastructure were among the worst in India. Nearly 60
            percent of homes in the state were not connected to roads,
            only 21 percent of households had access to piped water, and
            electricity was not available to the vast majority of
            households. International Bank for Reconstruction and
            Development (IBRD) supported Bihar government through Bihar
            Development Policy Loan to boost economic growth through
            reforms in agriculture, investment climate and basic
            infrastructure, with an emphasis on roads. The funding from
            IBRD helped create fiscal space for development by financing
            the government’s budgeted expenditures including retiring
            expensive public debt. Bihar’s tax revenues had increased by
            an impressive 19 percent annually since the reform program
            began. About 1,900 kilometers of the national highway along
            with 3,432 kilometers of district roads network were
            renovated by 2009. The government extended its midday meal
            scheme to cover children in grades six through eight,
            thereby increasing the program’s reach to nearly 11 million
            children. Bihar government, backed by World Bank funding and
            technical support, has helped Bihar improve public finance
            management and direct the proceeds toward getting more
            children into schools, immunization, and fighting corruption
